summary.seg: Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.5.76, written on paper in various hands, shows in its first section how closely related recipes for writing and decorating books are to those for medical healing. At the same time, the compiler also asserted the intellectual value of such craft knowledge by reference to venerable philosophical and medical authorities. Subsequently, the manuscript became a repository for short extracts from notable medical texts, namely the Dome of uryne by Henry Daniel (ff. 28r-29v), a rare Middle English treatise on wounds (ff. 30r-38v) based on Book Two of Guglielmo da Saliceto's Latin Cyrurgia, and an extract from a Latin alphabetical treatise on the properties of herbs (ff. 76r-93v). Its longest entry is a collection of about 350 medical and surgical recipes (ff. 39r-75v).

The manuscript had a long life as a resource for medical remedies and surgical treatments. A name or names of owners of a personal medical compilation ending on f. 26v have been erased from colophons on f. 27r. Johannes Bintreth/Buctreth is identified (f. 75r) as an owner of a book containing a rare Middle English wound treatise (ff. 30r-38v) and the larger collection of about 350 medical recipes (ff. 39r-75v). Throughout the manuscript, notes have been added by those through whose hands the manuscript passed, strongly suggesting that it was in use from the late 15th century into the 16th and early 17th centuries. To judge by repeated marginal notes to 'Take this', beginning on f. 7v, one reader intended to make his own compilation from the first collection of recipes. 16th- or 17th-century users added on a blank page (f. 27v) cures for stomach ailments attributed to doctors Smith, Lang, Walker and Barnesley. An anonymous user added occasional marginal clarifications to aid reading the text on the properties of herbs (ff. 76r-93v).

Part 1 of MS Dd.5.76, ff. 1r-26v, is a remarkable, deliberate personal compilation of craft recipes and medical recipes, the latter primarily for cankers, fevers, and wound care. The table of contents is prefaced by a unique copy of a Middle English poem, much damaged, in ten rhymed stanzas, constituting a devout penitential prayer. The rubric to the recipe collection appears in bright red ink immediately after the end of the poem (f. 2r), and the text of both were written by the same hand. The rubric reads 'Here begins the book of diverse materials and medicines and ointments' ('Hic incipit liber de diversis rebus et medicinis ac unguentis'), leaving little doubt that the artisanal and medical recipes to follow were conceived as one unit. This rubric continues by announcing that 'in the first place' stands the letter of Aristotle, sent to King Alexander regarding maintenance of the health of the human body ('In primis epistula aristotelis missa ad alexandrem regem de conseruacione humani corporis'). The text begins with the only decorated initial in this part of the manuscript. Latin versions of the letter of Aristotle to Alexander, known as the Secretum secretorum, appear in other late medieval manuscripts. Here, the letter of advice concerns personal habits, good and bad digestion, and ends with a summary of the best foods to be eaten in each season of the year. There then follows the list of the recipes to be included, corresponding to those copied into the text. However, between the table of contents and the recipes proper, the compiler inserted four items, not accounted for in the table of copied texts, which reveal his own interests (ff. 6v-7r): a charm for fevers, a 'marvelous drink' for canker and fistulas as well as internal poisons, and two Latin prayers, one to be spoken when making a medicine, and another to recite when administering a medicine.

The recipes identified in the table of contents cover eleven folios (ff. 7r-22r), and they begin with thirty craft recipes. Most of these would be useful to a scribe or illuminator of books, but there is also one for making soap that states at what point to 'set your mark on the cake', and one for dye to mark wool or wool sacks, both of which speak to wider commercial interests. One to retrieve gold or silver from an old ribbon even shows how to source these precious metals by recycling. Colour recipes as found in MS Dd.5.76 range from blacks, azure, vermilion, rose, white (ceruse), gold for illuminating letters, 'good' green, blue turnsole, and a colour 'like gold'. The ink recipes include 'Lombard ink', 'text ink' and 'black ink' as well as red, a 'fine rose' for writing and ruling pages. There are several recipes for making sizes or gums and recipes for multiplying the quantity of 'asure byce', turnsole, and wax.

The series of craft and medical recipes is divided by a rubric on f. 12v that establishes the authority of the medical cures and clarifies their purpose: 'Here begynnes a boke of gode medicines proued with gode clerkes and oþere maysters of fesik and vsed be þam for for cancres gode medicines prowed be maystere henri arden and oþere mo mastres'. 'Master Henri Arden' is probably a misidentification of the surgeon, John Arderne. What follows are more than eighty medical recipes beginning with ten for 'canker' (that is, ulcers of various types), followed by recipes for similarly painful gout, fester, sores, wounds and an 'enposteme' (an inflammation or swelling of bad humours). Ringworms, head lice, and a skin disease called 'the fire of hell' appear later in the list. Besides such skin lesions, there are remedies for internal diseases such as stomach pains and constipation and for swellings of the neck and liver. Six recipes concern removing or growing hair or colouring it black or brown. Other diseases warrant one or two remedies, although migraine headaches receive a total of five. The forms of the remedies offered as cures comprise twenty-four ointments, fourteen plasters, twenty-five drinks, three lectuaries or soft sweetened medicines, four medicines to be taken in small doses, and three powders. Frequently, the same ingredients used in recipes for inks, sizing, colours (white, green, blue, red) are also found in cures for canker, fester, and other external lesions as well as for internal diseases that were perceived to derive from corrupted humours and biting poisons. Similarly, a charm to cure fevers requires the direct application of ink.

In Part 2 of the manuscript, a scribe copied the first chapters of Henry Daniel's widely circulated Dome of uryne (ff. 28r-29v), which has been edited by M. Teresa Tavormina. The scribe elaborated the initial letter Ts with animal and human heads; these doodles are the only figural decoration in the whole manuscript. Whereas the rest of the manuscript's contents deal broadly with treatment, this text is the only one that addresses diagnosis, and specifically through urinoscopy. As the author explains, four elements belong to the 'dome of uryne' (i.e. the doom, or passing of judgement on, urine, from the Middle English verb 'domen'): the substance, colours, regions and contents. Is the substance thick or thin, or in between? If it is thin enough to see the joints of your fingers through it, Daniel wrote, 'that thynnes betokynneth a bad splene and a bad stomak and a watyr in the bowellys'. Thickness indicated a pain in the stomach, in the head and in the bowels, but somewhere in between indicated 'disease of the gall'. Of colour, Daniel explained that, 'as Masterys sayth', there were twenty possible colours of urine, and proceeded to describe these, beginning with the whitest, 'as clere watyr of the well'; unfortunately, the copy of the text preserved here ends imperfectly, part-way through the description of the sixteenth colour, which is 'as black wyne'.

In Part 3, the Middle English treatise on wounds is a loose translation of excerpts taken from Book Two of Guglielmo da Saliceto's Chirurgia, which was written in late 13th-century Italy. The original Latin text describes how a surgeon should cleanse, suture, and treat piercing wounds caused by swords and arrows and the like with numerous recipes for cleansing, closing, and soothing. The Cambridge Middle English wounds treatise begins in the middle of a sentence (f. 30r) in Book Two, Chapter Nine, on wounds to the arms and hands. It continues with excerpts from Chapters Twelve through Sixteen, covering (in order) wounds to the breast and ribs, back, mouth of the stomach (where the scribe adds a potion of Master William Holme, 'for men and wymen that weren woundid in the stomac' (f. 35r-35v)), the lower stomach and bowels, and finally the waist and the hips. Guglielmo's chapter numbers are not given, and the excerpts are arbitrary, but brief transitions in Latin mark the movement from one topic to another. A surgical operation and successful cure of a 'knight of Pavia' (Papia), 'Sire Johannes Deperdella', whom a 'master' named Octobonus considered untreatable, is described in as much or more detail in Middle English as in the Latin original (f. 37r-37v).

An acephalous collection of about 350 recipes and charms in Middle English (with some Latin in the charms) extends from f. 39r to f. 75v. The charms largely correspond to those found in other 15th-century medical recipe collections that are prefaced by a Middle English poem that promises medicines 'to hele sores boþ olde and newe', and 'To hele alle sores þat arn curable / Of swerd knif and of arue / Be þe wounde wyd or narue / Of spere of quarel of dagger of dart' (see also Cambridge, University Library, MS Add. 9308, f. 2r). This collection was copied by the same hand as the preceding treatise on wounds, and there is much here that addresses this same subject. There are directions for making the two cures named 'gracia dei', a salve or plaster for cleaning and healing wounds or ulcers. One, 'good for old sores and new', was used, it is claimed, by Lady Beauchamp, the wife of the earl of Warwick (f. 54r). Another 'the erle of hertford [sic] vsyd that was held a noble surgyn' (f. 54v). There are also instructions for constructing a surgical dressing for an open wound: it uses a lead plate etched with five crosses, which was to be prayed over and conjured with a charm by the virtue of the wounds of Christ. A small diagram of the plate itself is included (f. 67v; see also Cambridge, University Library, MS Ee.1.15, f. 94v).

Lea Olsan
Emerita Professor, Department of English
University of Louisiana at Monroe

listBibl.bibl: Lea T. Olsan, 'The corpus of charms in the Middle English leechcraft remedy books', in Charms, charmers and charming: international research on verbal magic', ed. by Jonathan Roper, Palgrave Historical Studies in Witchcraft and Magic (Basingstoke: Palgrave Macmillan, 2008), pp. 214-237

Lea T. Olsan, 'Pigmenta: materials for writing, painting and healing', in Manuscripts in the Making: Art and Science, ed. by Stella Panayotova and Paola Ricciardi, 2 vols (London: Harvey Miller, 2018), vol. 2, pp. 107-117
The dome of uryne: a reading edition of nine Middle English uroscopies, ed. by M. Teresa Tavormina (Oxford: University Press, 2019)
Steven J. Williams, The Secret of Secrets: the scholarly career of a pseudo-Aristotelian text in the Latin Middle Ages (Ann Arbor (MI): University of Michigan Press, 2003)

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.
The folio numbers between f. 84 and f. 89 are out of sequence - 87, 88, 85, 86 - reflecting the correct order of the text.
The last four foliated leaves (ff. 89-93) are blank modern paper leaves that originally served as flyleaves.

collation.p: Whereas A Catalogue of the Manuscripts Preserved in the Library of the University of Cambridge, 5 vols (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1856-1867), I and Connolly (2009) divide the manuscript into five separate parts, this catalogue record identifies only four parts, and (again unlike these publications) it also identifies f. 27 not as a separate codicological unit but as part of Part 1, as is supported by the collation and watermarks.
collation.formula: 110 212 312-7 (5th, 7th-12th not present) | 412 | 514-1 (10th not present) 612 710 812-1 (12th not present) | 9-102 1110

additions.p: Collation formula recording the structure of the leaves 'before re-binding in 1956', written by the hand of H.L. Pink, c. 1958 (inscribed on the inside of the lower cover).

binding.p: Quarter binding of brown leather with marbled paper sides, bound by Gray of Cambridge as indicated by a stamp on the inside of the upper cover.

provenance.p: John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : no. 772 (inscribed on f. 1r) in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697).

history.acquisition: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 : donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736 on the inside of the upper cover.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the description provided by Margaret Connolly, Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo), The Index of Middle English Prose (Woodbridge: Brewer, 2009), pp. 26-30, and an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.5.76, ff. 1-27

msItem.title: Verse prayer on the Words of Christ from the Cross
msItem.incipit: 1r And as þy worde ca[m] on þis wyse / To þe thefe with þ[e] in paradyse
msItem.explicit: 2r Thorow prayer of þi modere fre / Maydene mare mylde Amen

msItem.title: Table of contents listing 104 recipes
msItem.rubric: 2r Hic incipit liber de diuersis rebus et medicinis ac unguentis in primis epistola aristotelis missa ad alexandrum regem de conseruacione humani corporis
msItem.incipit: 2r ffor to make ynke lumbarde

msItem.title: Letter to Alexander (Secretum Secretorum)
msItem.author: Pseudo-Aristotle
msItem.rubric: 3v Epistola aristotelis missa ad alexandrem regem de conseruacione humani corporis sic incipit
msItem.incipit: 3v Alexander cum corpus habes corruptibile
msItem.explicit: 5v Et a medio decembris usque ad medium marcii yemps finitur ubi uer incipit. Vale

msItem.title: Charm for fever
msItem.textLang: Latin text with a Middle English rubric
msItem.rubric: 5v A gode charme for þe feuer profed
msItem.incipit: 5v In nomine patris + et filij + et Christus sancti + Amen
msItem.explicit: 6r libera famulum tuum uel famulam tuam .N. ab omni specie diuersarum februum ubiqucmque semper custodiat me die ac nocie Amen

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.rubric: A marueylious drynk and a gode for it helpes bothe cankere and fistila and also within as withoute and it wil do away þes scabbe in parti of þe body and it consumes venomes and clenses crosules and alle superfluytes of þe body þat comes of venomos humeros it destroyes alle maner of woundes newe olde it helis and clensis þam and it es made þusse
msItem.incipit: 6r Take gencyan, diptayne. astrologie
msItem.explicit: 6v and stop þe vessell mowthe well for þe ayre þat non ayre com þar to and use þis at euyn last and at morne fastande

msItem.title: Prayer to be recited when making medicines
msItem.textLang: Latin prayer with a Middle English rubric
msItem.rubric: 6v here begynnes a gode orysoun for to say when þou makes a medicyne to giffe or to do to any creature þat god has wrought and þus it begynnes
msItem.incipit: 6v-7r Deus qui creasti hominem et mirabiliter reformasti et qui dedisti medicinam ad recupandam sanitatem humanorum corporum da benedictionem tuam super hoc antedotum ut in quorum corporum interuenerit sanitatem accipere mereantur Per dominum nostrum ihesum Christum et cetera

msItem.title: Prayer to be recited when administraing medicines
msItem.textLang: Latin prayer with a Middle English rubric
msItem.rubric: 7r And when þou gefes any man or woman or any creature any medycine say to þam on þis wise
msItem.incipit: 7r In nomine sancte et indiuidue trinitatis + sit tibi hec medicina causa sanitatis + In nomine patris et filij spiritus sancti Amen +

msItem.title: Collection of 28 recipes for making black and coloured ink, glue and gilt
msItem.incipit: 7r For to make ynke lombarde do þusse take a nounce of gallis and breke þam in a morter all
msItem.explicit: 12v makyng þat it sand no lengar on þe fir þanne it be moltoun for if it do it will waste and wax blak and noght worth

msItem.title: Collection of ninety medical recipes
msItem.rubric: 12v Here begynnes a boke of gode medicines proued wiþ gode clerkes and oþer maystres of fesik and used be þam for cancres gode medicines prowed be mayster henri arden and oþer mo maystres
msItem.incipit: 12v Take þe hede of a crawe and þe fete and þe boweles and drye þam in a nowen til it be al to powder
msItem.explicit: 22r and so if þou will hafe it laxatife or constipatyfe take of þe herbes þat are of þat vertu and do wiþ þam as y sayde of þe squylle

msItem.title: Explanation of terms
msItem.incipit: 22r Oximellum est due partes aceti

msItem.title: On the weight of coins
msItem.textLang: Latin text with a Middle English rubric
msItem.incipit: 22v Scrupulus est pondus unius denarij
msItem.explicit: 22v Et nota [...] quia omnia qui in mortare teneritur debent ponderari per libram maiorem .i. xxv s'.

msItem.title: Collection of twenty recipes
msItem.incipit: 22v ffor to withe if a man schall lif or die of alle maner of sekenes: Take a handefulle of rew and stampe it in oyle of roses
msItem.explicit: 22v and menge it wiþ wyne and wiþ water bot þe two partes sall be wyne and gif him to drynke before þe acces come on him
msItem.note: The collection opens with prognostic recipes to determine whether a patient shall live or die. It also includes a charm against all fevers on ff. 24r.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 28.

msItem.title: Reference to a fever charm
msItem.rubric: 25r Seke in þe .vij. lef of þe furste quayere a faire charme for þe feueres
msItem.note: The reference is rubricated in red ink.

msItem.title: Rules for accounting
msItem.incipit: 25r Quadrantes sabbato quotquot expendivus anno / Tot crescunt solidi cum tot nummis numerati
msItem.explicit: 26r xl li. per diem - xiij Ml .vj.C li

msItem.title: List of English kings from William I to Henry VI
msItem.incipit: 26v Memorandum de regibus a conquestu et quot annos regnauerunt.

msItem.title: Sum of taxes from the Province of Canterbury and York
msItem.incipit: 26v Summe taxacionis temporalium et spiritualium cantuariensis prouincie

msItem.title: List of payments
msItem.incipit: 27r In primis de Johanne nottwyn per ffratri - vj s
msItem.note: Added in the late 15th century or early 16th century.

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 27v for the preservation of your stomach
msItem.explicit: 27v A draught of burtn malmesye otherwhiles, wilbe good for the stomacke
msItem.note: Added in the late 16th or early 17th century and attributed to Doctors Smith, Lang, Walker, and Barnesley.

p.secFol: 2r Here salle þou wone with myne Angelis

Paper folded in quarto.

list.item: Quire 312-7 (ff. 23r-27v: 5th leaf, after f. 26, and 7th-12th leaves, after f. 27, not present)

catchwords.seg: Catchwords on the lower right-hand corners of the last versos of quires

supportDesc.condition: The first leaf is fragmentary and has lost a section of its lower half, which has been repaired with blank paper. The upper right-hand corners of most leaves (except ff. 16-18) have been torn off and replaced with blank paper.

layout.seg: Ruled in ink, frame only. Single columns. 27 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: ff. 1r-26r is written by a single hand writing in an Anglicana script.
f. 26v is written by a single hand writing in an Anglicana script.
ff. 27r-27v contain additions by two hands writing in Secretary scripts, the first one dating to the late 15th or early 16th century and the second one to the late 16th or early 17th century .

decoNote.p: One large (3-line) initial in red ink on f. 3v.

provenance.p: An unknown owner in the late 15th or early 16th century: their incomplete ownership inscription on f. 27r: Iste liber constat. Another such inscription, of similar date and written above this one, has since been erased.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.5.76, ff. 28r-29v

msItem.title: The Doom of Urines (incomplete)
msItem.incipit: 28r In the begynnyng thow shalt tak hede to foure that longyth to dome of uryn þat is to say to the substans to the colours to regions and to the contentis
msItem.explicit: 29v The syxtene coloure is as blak wyne or the syxtene c

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), pp. 28-29

p.secFol: 29r thyn in harwyst and in wyntyr

supportDesc.condition: The pages contain stains and dirt, especially affecting the text's legibility on f. 29v. The upper right-hand corners have been torn off and replaced with blank paper.

layout.seg: No ruling. Single columns. 21-22 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Written by a single hand in a Secretary script.

decoNote.p: Large (6-line) initial in red ink with crosses in brown ink drawn inside the letter and featuring a human face (f. 28r).
Large (2-line) initials in brown ink with human, zoomorphic or hybrid heads protruding from them into the margins throughout.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.5.76, ff. 30r-75v

msItem.title: On the Treatment of Wounds
msItem.author: Guglielmo da Saliceto
msItem.incipit: 30r and thou schalt putte alle thine entent forto conforte the place aboute with bole armoniak and oile of rose a litil vineger medlid togedir
msItem.explicit: 38v he schalle be domede to be deed for the bleddir may take no confondinge for it is a sinowy place at the sinowis
msItem.note: Extracts from Book Two, Chapters 9 and 12-16, of Saliceto's Latin Chirurgia. One recipe on f. 35r is entitled Pocio Magistri Wilhelmi Holme (presumably the Franciscan William Holme, author of Tractatus de medicinis (c. 1400) and De simplicibus medicinis (c. 1415)).

msItem.title: Collection of c. 350 medical recipes and charms
msItem.incipit: 39r ffor the cynke: Take the Roote of horshelue and the roote of conseoie of euery iliche and grinde hem smalle in a morter
msItem.explicit: 75v whanne thou haste so doo cast theron francencens mastic mirre of eche half an ounce and so lat it boyle oon the fyre sayinge thre pater noster etcaetera
msItem.note: The collection includes a recipe for Gracia dei on f. 54r that is said to have bene used by the lady beauchampe the erlys wife of warwik.

supportDesc.support: Paper folded in quarto. Two-headed unicorn (?).

list.item: Quire 514-1 (ff. 30-42: 10th leaf, after f. 38, is not present)
Quire 812-1 (ff. 65-75: 12th leaf, after f. 64, not present)

supportDesc.condition: The upper right-hand corner of f. 55 and the upper edge of f. 74 have been torn off and replaced with blank paper.

layout.seg: Ruled in ink, frames only. Double columns. 27-35 lines to the page, below the top line.

handNote.p: Written by a single hand writing in a cursive script with both Anglicana and Secretary features.

decoNote.p: Spaces left blank for small (1-line) initials throughout.

history.provenance: Johannes Bintreth/Buctreth Bintreth/Buctreth, Johannes: his name in a colophon on f. 75v: Iste lybro constat Johannes Buctre [th] [Connolly: Bintreth] quod Johannes Bradley.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.6.76, ff. 76r-93v

msItem.title: Treatise on the properties of herbs, alphabetically organised (fragment)
msItem.incipit: 76r [...] et scorp[iones]. Carnes [...]
msItem.explicit: 89v et incarnat et consolidat ea et abs[...]it obscuritatem"
msItem.note: The treatise starts in the letter 'C' ('Crisomila meliora') and ends in the letter 'E' ('Es').

foliation.note: Arabic numbers in brown ink right-hand corner of the rectos of ff. 79r-89r.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in the lower right-hand corners of the last versos of quires.

supportDesc.condition: The upper edges of most leaves have been torn and replaced with blank paper.

layout.seg: No ruling visible. Single columns. 29 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Copied by a single hand in a Secretary script.

decoNote.p: The names of herbs have been underlined in red throughout.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer, Cambridge University Library
